message.content:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: 
public void drop(String name){
    Iterator<Item> it = myArray.iterator();
    while(it.hasNext()){
        Item count = it.next();
        if(count.getName().contains(name)){
            if(currentRoom.hasItem() == false){
                currentRoom.addItem(count);
                currentMessage = "you have successfully dropped the item in the room";
                it.remove();
                return;
            } else {
                currentMessage = "the room already has an item";
                return;
            }
        }
    }
    currentMessage = "you do not have that item";
}
<<<explanation>>>: You should not remove an item from a list while iterating over it with a for-each loop, as it can cause ConcurrentModificationException. Instead, use an Iterator. The Iterator's remove() method removes the last element returned by the iterator. It is the only safe way to modify a collection during iteration. Also, once you've found the item and handled it, you should return from the method to prevent the "you do not have that item" message from always being set.
